text: What’s up smart people. Joe here. It's time for the big game. You know the one…the game,

with the guys, on the field, in the pads,
with the ball…you know…
PBS Sports Presents…

The Superb Owl! (*totally 100% not infringing
on copyright* graphic)

There’s been one team in the bird league
this year that’s been dominating

the rest, we’re talkin’ skill, agility, speed, the ability to fly, and enormous talons
at every position,
ready to get OWL up in your grill… let’s meet the team!

On the ground or in the air,
these guys are deadly… ok maybe not with
an actual football, maybe more like a mouse…

Owls need sensory super powers because they’ve
gotta be efficient hunting machines. A barn

owl could easily have 7 owl babies, each needin’
to eat 5 mice a day. Got the big eaters in

there! And since they only hunt at night,
that’s 6 hours to gain 35 mice.

To make the most of every play, you’ve gotta
be able to see the field. Luckily, relative

to body size owls have gigantic eyes, maximum
visual sensitivity in low-light. Owl peepers

are so big, regular sphere-shaped eyeballs
like ours wouldn’t leave any room for bird brains

Solution? Tubular eyes. They
get a larger eye opening and it keeps their
skull small. That's a win-win baby.
But the drawback of tubular eyes means you can’t move 'em in your sockets, but luckily owls

can go full Exorcist, they can rotate their heads
around up to 270 degrees.

Now great vision is one skill, but these guys
are the total package! When it’s too dark
to see, they pull a special page from their playbook. Their owl ears.

Except those aren’t
actually ears. Their whole face is an ear.

Owl faces may look flat, but that’s just
a feathery fakeout. This is ruff. A facial
ruff!

Let’s take apart this key to the game™.
The ruff has two different types of feathers.

You got your guys in the middle here to protect
the face and eyes, and these guys out here

on the edge? they can move either way. They
reflect sound towards a couple asymmetrically

placed receivers, these guys hit the perfect
angle to create super-hearing.

Talk about a hoot! Their face is basically
a sound collecting radar dish. Their hearing’s

so good, they can even hunt mice underneath
snow. Focus on the sound, swoop in, and it’s
game over.

Rounding out this total skill package, owls
have even evolved silent flight.

Just look at that wingspan! When you’ve
got big flappers compared to your body size,

you can fly slowly and create less noise.
The front edge of that wing is serrated to

dampen sound, it’s like velvet, baby! While
that front edge is laying out lead blocking

on the passing air, the trailing edge has
this fringed texture, that means less drag,
all speed. You hear that? Me neither!

You don’t have to be Owlbert Einstein to
see these guys are basically perfect stealth

flying machines! We’ve got engineers studying
them to figure out how to make quieter planes
and drones. Which.. is.. terrifying.

When they hit paydirt they swallow their food
pretty much whole. Then what goes down comes

back up a few hours later, basically a well-preserved
pack of undigested bones and fur. That’s

disgusting, but useful, it can give you a play
by play of what species the owl ate.

When scientists find old, preserved owl pellets,
they can study how small mammal communities

have changed over thousands of years, it’s
a whole history recorded in owl food!

Owls may not have the passing ability of a
guy like Tom Brady, but when you can see and

hear the field like that… Superb Owls? They’re
champs!
Stay curious! And don't miss our halftime show: Deadmouse!
